 December 01, 2006 19:00
 US manufacturing contracted in November for the first time in three and a half years, while construction spending fell sharply in October, according to reports today pointing to a slowdown in the US economy.

 Public companies receive no direct benefit from retirement fund contributions other than driving their stock. 401k contributions are used to purchase their stock. While some company benefit may be derived by increased stock value expanding credit facilities due to a balance sheet equity increase (and increasing senior management bonuses), there are no direct infusions of capital from 401k programs to anyone other than the investment firms and that's in the form of fee revenue. That's what tanked .com 401k contributors and then Enron 401k holders as the bulk had to be put into company stock. Most successful public US companies have been awash in cash due to lack of expansion. There hasn't been any US demand for expansion capital for years. We have capital flight. 
 
 As anyone other than MM who contributes to this topic can tell you, 2-3% inflation is far from being a realistic inflation number. There's no energy, food or monetary inflation in that number. In a circumstance I'm currently involved in, we're looking at 8% as a minimum inflation factor and we won't use US equity stocks as a hedge due to their sensitivity to current inflation and future baby boomer demands. Once baby boomers stop contributions and begin serious draw downs on their 401k accounts, equity markets are going to get interesting. 
 
 I like S&P reports for large cap reports, but medium and small public companies (and some large ones) have gone from fiddling with revenue to fiddling with cash flow to enhance their paper appearances. I do not consider any equity market stock price as anything other than people buying or selling that particular issue, nor do I consider market trends to have anything to do with anything but earnings reports. Anyone can fiddle with earnings or cash flow and look great for a certain period of time, especially at calender year-end when senior bonuses are often calculated with company equity positions as a bonus component.
